choices.text: PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.
PHPV is frequently associated with Down syndrome.
Anterior PHPV generally has a poor prognosis due to the high likelihood of amblyopia.
Calcification is a common finding in PHPV and should be expected in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of an infant with PHPV?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.

 

  • True, PHPV is a developmental anomaly that occurs due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress and can present with leukocoria (true white pupil).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PHPV is frequently associated with Down syndrome: False, PHPV is not associated with Down syndrome, but rather can be associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13).

 

Option C. Anterior PHPV generally has a poor prognosis due to the high likelihood of amblyopia: False, anterior PHPV generally has a good prognosis if managed appropriately, with the risk of amblyopia being the primary concern.

 

Option D. Calcification is a common finding in PHPV and should be expected in this case: False, calcification is not typically seen in PHPV; it is more commonly associated with retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a non-hereditary, congenital anomaly due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress, often presenting unilaterally with leukocoria, and is associated with a good prognosis when anterior without calcification.

choices.text: The person appears confused to the onlookers
Remote memory is relatively intact during the blackout
It is a discrete episode of anterograde amnesia
It is associated with alcohol intoxication

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about blackouts except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The person appears confused to the onlookers

 

  • During a blackout, especially those related to alcohol intoxication, the individual can engage in complex behaviors that might seem normal to observers; they do not necessarily appear confused. Blackouts involve an episode of anterograde amnesia, during which the individual is unable to form new memories but does not necessarily exhibit overt signs of confusion at the time of the event.
  • The person experiencing a blackout typically has impaired short-term memory and impaired ability to form new memories (anterograde amnesia) but can retain long-standing, well-consolidated remote memories and can often carry out routine or familiar tasks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remote memory is relatively intact during the blackout: This is true; during a blackout, remote memory, which pertains to memories formed before the onset of the blackout, remains intact.

 

Option C. It is a discrete episode of anterograde amnesia: This is also true. A blackout is an episode where the person cannot create new memories, hence the term 'anterograde amnesia'.

 

Option D. It is associated with alcohol intoxication: True, blackouts are commonly associated with alcohol intoxication, which can disrupt the brain's ability to create new memories.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A blackout, often induced by alcohol intoxication, is characterized by an episode of anterograde amnesia without the overt appearance of confusion or disorientation.
  • Individuals may appear to be functioning normally to onlooker’s despite being unable to form new memories.

questions.text: In a pediatric patient at high risk for severe respiratory illness, Palivizumab can be administered to prevent complications associated with which viral infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory syncytial virus

 

  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the leading cause of bronchiolitis in infants, and palivizumab is an approved monoclonal antibody for its prevention in high-risk children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avian influenzae: Avian influenza, often caused by the H5N1 virus, can lead to severe respiratory illness, but there is no monoclonal antibody currently approved for its prevention.

 

Option B. Parainfluenzae: Parainfluenza viruses cause respiratory illnesses, but there is no specific monoclonal antibody used for prophylaxis against these viruses.

 

Option D. Coxsackie virus: Coxsackie virus, a cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, among other syndromes, does not have a monoclonal antibody available for prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for the prevention of serious lower respiratory tract disease caused by RSV in children at high risk for RSV disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old university student had a fight with the neighbouring boy. On the next day while out, he started feeling that two men in police uniform were observing his movements. When he reached home in the evening he was frightened and told his family members that police were after him and would arrest him. Despite reassurances by family members, he remained afraid that he is about to be arrested. The history is suggestive of which psychiatric sign/symptom:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delusion of persecution

 

  • A delusion of persecution is a firm and false belief that others are out to harm or harass the individual.
  • In this case, the student's unfounded fear that the police are observing him and planning to arrest him suggests a persecutory delusion, a common type of delusional thinking found in various psychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia and delusional disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusion of reference: This involves the belief that commonplace occurrences or remarks are specifically directed at oneself. If the student believed that the police officers were giving him signs or messages specifically related to him, it might suggest a delusion of reference, but the information given highlights fear of arrest rather than interpreted messages.

 

Option C. Somatic passivity: This refers to the sensation that external forces are acting on the body or influencing bodily functions, which is not suggested by the history provided.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: This is the belief that thoughts that are not one's own are being inserted into one's mind. The student's fear is not described as an inserted thought but rather as a fixed, false belief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The history is suggestive of a delusion of persecution, which is a belief that one is going to be harmed by others – in this case, the police.
  • It's a common symptom in psychiatric conditions such as psychosis where the individual's belief system is out of touch with reality.

questions.text: A male patient with benign hypertrophy of the prostate was hospitalized for three weeks. During his stay, he developed signs suggestive of a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The tip of his urinary catheter was cultured on blood agar and, after 24 hours, the agar showed the distinctive pattern as in the image provided. Which organism is most likely the causative agent of the UTI in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteus mirabilis

 

  • The culture shown on the blood agar plate exhibits a characteristic "swarming" pattern, a phenomenon commonly associated with Proteus mirabilis due to its motility.
  • This bacterium is known for its ability to rapidly spread across the surface of agar plates due to flagella-mediated motility, creating concentric rings as it periodically swarms and then consolidates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: Typically produces a greenish pigment (pyocyanin) on blood agar and does not show a swarming pattern.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Generally, does not exhibit swarming on blood agar and would show isolated colonies.

 

Option D. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Known to produce mucoid colonies due to its polysaccharide capsule but does not swarm on agar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blood agar with swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.

choices.text: This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint
Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint
Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible
Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint

questions.text: A student after a heavy lunch from the hostel got ready for his afternoon class. After a while he yawned widely. To his surprise sadly he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck. Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

 

  • The medial pterygoid muscle, along with the lateral pterygoid, masseter, and temporalis muscles, is one of the muscles of mastication.
  • The primary action of the medial pterygoid muscle is elevation of the mandible, not depression.
  • The depression of the mandible, or opening the mouth, is primarily accomplished by the lateral pterygoid muscle and the suprahyoid muscles, especially when the mouth is opened wide, as in a yawn.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint: This is likely true given the scenario where the student is unable to close his mouth after a wide yawn, which can cause an anterior dislocation of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

 

Option B. Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint: This is true. The TMJ is a type of synovial joint that involves the condyle of the mandible and the articular fossa of the temporal bone.

 

Option D. Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint: This is also true. The sphenomandibular ligament is one of the ligaments of the TMJ located medially to the joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The medial pterygoid muscle functions to elevate the mandible, not depress it. In the context of a TMJ dislocation, which often occurs with an anterior dislocation after activities such as yawning, the inability to close the mouth is a key clinical sign.
  • Understanding the anatomy and function of the muscles of mastication and the ligaments of the TMJ is important for diagnosing and managing TMJ disorders.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements: 

 

  1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases
  2. All patients after trauma with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury
  3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma
  4. The first step in primary survey in field trauma patient is control of any exsanguinating hemorrhage
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2,4

 

Explanation:

 

Based on the given statements, let's identify the correct ones regarding the management of trauma patients:

 

1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases This statement is incorrect. Tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce the risk of mortality from bleeding in both penetrating and blunt trauma cases, as evidenced by the CRASH-2 trial.

 

2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury This statement is correct. The CRASH-2 trial also indicated that tranexamic acid is beneficial when administered within 3 hours of injury to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage or shock.

 

3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma This statement is incorrect. In severely hypovolemic trauma patients, blood and blood products are preferred to restore circulating volume and oxygen-carrying capacity. Crystalloids can be used temporarily while awaiting blood products but are not the resuscitation fluid of choice in severe hemorrhage.

 

4. The first step in primary survey in field trauma patient is control of any exsanguinating haemorrhage This statement is correct. In trauma care, particularly in the pre-hospital setting, the first step in the primary survey is to control any life-threatening external hemorrhage before proceeding with airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) assessment and management.

 

The correct options, therefore, are 2 and 4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key points in trauma management include administering tranexamic acid within 3 hours to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage, using blood and blood products for the resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients, and controlling life-threatening hemorrhage as a first step in the primary survey of trauma patients.

choices.text: Pain or decreased range of motion on active and passive movement both
Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with musculoskeletal pain localized to her right    shoulder. She reports the pain intensifies during her daily activities such as lifting objects but eases when at rest without movement. Radiographs of the shoulder show no joint space narrowing or bony abnormalities. Which of the following features most strongly suggests a non-articular origin for her shoulder pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

 

  • Non-articular pain often arises from structures such as tendons, bursae, or muscles rather than the joint itself.
  • This type of pain typically does not occur with passive movement of a joint because passive movement does not engage these structures as actively does.
  • In contrast, articular pain is typically present with both active and passive movements due to the involvement of the joint structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain or decreased range of motion on active and passive movement both: Pain or decreased range of motion on active and passive movement both are more indicative of articular problems.

 

Option B. Swelling around the joint: Swelling is generally associated with joint (articular) issues.

 

Option C. Crepitus on joint movement: Crepitus on joint movement can indicate articular cartilage damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ability to differentiate non-articular from articular pain is essential in musculoskeletal assessment.
  • Non-articular pain typically occurs with active but not passive movement, suggesting involvement of periarticular tissues like muscles or tendons rather than the joint itself.

choices.text: Antidepressant with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Guidance and recounseling with guru plus antidepressant

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought by his wife. He thinks that he had committed sins throughout his life. He is very much depressed and has considered committing suicide but has not taken any such steps. He is also taking sessions with a spiritual guru. He does not get convinced when his wife tells him that he has led a pious life. How will you treat him?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antipsychotic plus antidepressant

 

  • The presence of depressive symptoms with persistent beliefs about having committed sins—beliefs that may suggest delusional thinking—can indicate a major depressive disorder with psychotic features.
  • Antipsychotic medications are effective for the management of psychosis, and when combined with antidepressants, they address both the depressive and psychotic aspects of the illness.
  • The persistence and fixed nature of his beliefs, despite evidence to the contrary, and his preoccupation with these beliefs suggest the possibility of psychosis, necessitating the use of antipsychotics in conjunction with antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antidepressant with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT): While CBT combined with antidepressants is a strong treatment for major depression, if the patient's symptoms include delusions, which are a form of psychosis, CBT alone may not be effective in addressing these symptoms.

 

Option C. Guidance and recounseling with guru plus antidepressant: This option might provide support and could be beneficial in the context of the patient's spiritual concerns. However, it may not sufficiently address potential psychotic symptoms that require specific medical treatment.

 

Option D. Antidepressant alone: For depressive symptoms without psychosis, an antidepressant alone might be sufficient. However, in the presence of delusional thinking, additional treatment with an antipsychotic is usually indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient exhibiting signs of depression coupled with delusional guilt, the treatment plan should include both an antidepressant to manage the mood disorder and an antipsychotic to address psychotic symptoms.

choices.text: Who have residual weakness 6 months after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.
Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.
Who have residual weakness 6 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.
Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, wild polio virus is isolated.

questions.text: Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis is defined as those cases of acute flaccid paralysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated


Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) is a rare but recognized adverse event associated with the live oral polio vaccine (OPV). It occurs when the attenuated virus in the vaccine reverts to a neurovirulent form, leading to paralysis. VAPP typically occurs in recipients of OPV or their close contacts, highlighting the importance of moving towards inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) to mitigate this risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) is defined as those cases of AFP which have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine-related poliovirus but no wild poliovirus is isolated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a sudden, severe headache, visual disturbances, and difficulty moving the left eye inwards. Imaging reveals an aneurysm near the Circle of Willis. Which cranial nerve is most likely to be compressed between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery due to the aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oculomotor Nerve

 

  • The Oculomotor nerve lies between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery. Superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery arises from basilar artery.

 

 

 

  • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil. It also plays a role in raising the eyelid.
  • In cases of an aneurysm near the Circle of Willis, the oculomotor nerve (Cranial nerve III) is at risk of being compressed between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery.
  • This compression can lead to symptoms such as headache, visual disturbances, and eye movement difficulties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic Nerve: Optic Nerve is responsible for vision. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain. The optic nerve does not typically run between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery. It is primarily associated with the visual pathway and does not course through the same region as the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option C. Abducens Nerve:  Abducens Nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally. The abducens nerve has a different course within the brainstem and is not typically situated between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery.

 

Option D. Trigeminal Nerve: Trigeminal Nerve is responsible for sensory functions in the face, including touch, temperature, and pain, and controls the muscles of mastication. The trigeminal nerve has a different course and location in the brainstem compared to the oculomotor nerve, and it does not typically run between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Occulomotor Nerve:
     
    • The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil.
    • It also plays a role in raising the eyelid.
    • It is the cranial nerve that runs between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery as it courses through the interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem.

choices.text: Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive
Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with a two-day history of fever and altered mental status. On examination, her legs are covered with the rash pictured, her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and neck stiffness is noted. Laboratory analysis of lumbar puncture samples reveals cloudy, turbid cerebrospinal fluid with a white cell count of 4200 cells/µL, protein level of 168, and glucose of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely Gram stain characteristic of the organism responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

 

  • The correct answer is (b) Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose.
  • This description fits Neisseria meningitidis, the causative agent of meningococcal meningitis, which often presents with a petechial or purpuric rash, fever, altered mental status, hypotension, and neck stiffness.
  • The laboratory findings from the CSF are consistent with bacterial meningitis—elevated white cell count, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. N. meningitidis is oxidase positive and ferments both glucose and maltose, which helps distinguish it from other Gram-negative organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram-negative diplococci (kidney-shaped), oxidase positive: This is typically descriptive of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which does not cause meningitis with a rash.

 

Option C. Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive: These characteristics describe Streptococcus pyogenes, which does not typically cause meningitis.

 

Option D. Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive: This describes Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of meningitis, but the rapid onset and distinctive rash are more characteristic of N. meningitidis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical history of meningitis with a typical purpuric rash is seen in Meningococcal infection. Meningococci are Gram Negative diplococci, ferment glucose and maltose both, in contrast to gonococci which ferment only glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following features are seen by the lesion of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans: D) Contralateral Hemiplegia

 

  • Marked structure is a pyramid on the ventral surface of medulla just lateral to anterior median fissure.
  • The corticospinal fibres lie underneath the pyramid. Lesion of which will cause contralateral hemiplegia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to a lack of muscle coordination that can affect speech, eye movements, the ability to swallow, walking, and other voluntary movements. It is commonly associated with lesions in the cerebellum or in the sensory pathways.

 

Option B. Vertigo: Vertigo is a sense of spinning or dizziness, often related to problems in the inner ear or vestibular system. Lesions in the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem, the vestibulocochlear nerve, or the inner ear can lead to vertigo.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral Facial Nerve Palsy: Ipsilateral Facial Nerve Palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles on the same side as the lesion. It is commonly associated with lesions affecting the facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII), which could be at the level of the brainstem or the nerve itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Contralateral Hemiplegia:  This is paralysis on the side of the body opposite to the side of the brain where the lesion is located.
  • Lesions in the motor pathways, especially in the cerebral cortex or internal capsule, can lead to contralateral hemiplegia because motor fibers decussate (cross over) in the medulla.

choices.text: Levels I, II, III
Levels I to V
Levels II to IV
Levels II to V

questions.text: In a patient undergoing treatment for head and neck cancer, the decision on the extent of neck dissection is crucial. A supra omohyoid selective neck dissection involves the removal of which levels of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Levels I, II, III

 

Levels I, II, III: These are the lymph node levels typically removed in a supraomohyoid neck dissection, which is often used for cancers of the oral cavity where these node levels are most likely to contain metastases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levels I to V: This is too extensive for a selective neck dissection and is more in line with modified radical neck dissection (MRND), which removes all lymphatic tissue in the neck.

 

Option C. Levels II to IV: These levels would be more indicative of a lateral neck dissection, which is typically used for cancers that have spread laterally in the neck.

 

Option D. Levels II to V: This option would suggest a posterolateral neck dissection, which is less common and usually indicated for certain types of cancers like melanoma or squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The supraomohyoid selective neck dissection typically involves removal of lymph nodes at levels I, II, and III and is used primarily for oral cavity cancers where these levels are most commonly affected by metastases.

choices.text: Flexor digitorum profundus
Flexor carpi radialis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty bringing his fingers together and separating them. He also mentions that he has trouble bending his fingers at the knuckles while keeping the rest of the finger straight. Physical examination reveals atrophy in the spaces between the bones of the hand. Based on the patient's symptoms and physical exam findings, which group of muscles is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interossei

 

  • The interossei muscles are responsible for the adduction and abduction of the fingers. Paralysis of these muscles leads to difficulty in adducting the fingers.
  • Additionally, the lumbricals, when affected, lead to difficulty in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints while extending the interphalangeal joints.
  • However, the interossei have a more prominent role in adducting the fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbricals: They assist with flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints, but the primary issue described is with adduction, which is more related to the interossei.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum profundus: This muscle is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers, not adduction.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis: This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist, not the fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The interossei muscles are primarily responsible for adducting and abducting the fingers, and their paralysis can lead to difficulty in performing these actions. The lumbricals contribute to flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints, but they are not the primary muscles for finger adduction.

choices.text: Acute rheumatic fever
Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a four-day history of sore throat. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils with a yellow-grayish exudate and a pronounced foul odor. He has a high fever and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following non-suppurative complications should be of concern in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

 

  • Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis are potential non-suppurative complications of group A streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • These complications result from the body's immune response to the infection, rather than direct bacterial invasion.

 

Option A. Acute rheumatic fever: Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a non-suppurative complication of streptococcal pharyngitis that can result in cardiac valvular damage, arthritis, Sydenham's chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: Acute glomerulonephritis, specifically post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, can occur after streptococcal pharyngitis or skin infection, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension due to immune complex deposition in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is associated with streptococcal pharyngitis and is characterized by a distinctive rash, "strawberry tongue," and fever. It is typically a suppurative complication that results directly from toxins produced by the streptococcal bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient presents with pharyngitis and the mentioned clinical features, it is crucial to consider both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis as potential non-suppurative complications, especially in the context of streptococcal infection.

questions.text: In a clinical assessment scenario, a patient presents with symptoms indicative of a respiratory infection, characterized by cough with rusty sputum, lower lobe consolidation, and bronchial breath sounds. The organism responsible for this infection was also found to give a positive Quellung reaction. Based on these clinical and laboratory findings, what is the probable Gram staining appearance of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gram-positive cocci

 

  • The clinical presentation of cough with rusty sputum, along with lower lobe consolidation and bronchial breath sounds, strongly suggests pneumonia. The description of a positive Quellung reaction is characteristic of
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is a Gram-positive cocci. This test is specific for the presence of the capsule that is typical of certain bacteria, including S. pneumoniae, and the capsular swelling observed indicates a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram-negative bacilli: This option would be incorrect as it does not describe the morphology typical of S. pneumoniae, which is known to be Gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Gram-positive bacilli: This also is not consistent with the characteristics of S. pneumoniae, which is not bacilli in shape.

 

Option D. Gram-negative diplococci: Although Neisseria species, which are Gram-negative diplococci, can cause respiratory symptoms, they do not produce rusty sputum and do not yield a positive Quellung reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • History of lobar consolidation –indicates lobar pneumonia
  • Quellung test positive- indicates pneumococcal pneumonia
  • Pneumococci are Gram positive diplococci, lanceolate shaped

choices.text: The SA Node is supplied by Left Coronary Artery
Coronary predominance is based on origin of Anterior Interventricular Branch
The Interventricular Septum is supplied only by Right Coronary Artery
The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short

questions.text: Which of the following is true about arterial supply to the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short

 

  • The left coronary artery (LCA) typically has a very short main trunk that bifurcates into the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and the left circumflex (LCx) artery.
  • This short trunk arises from the aorta and is an important feature in coronary angiography, as the bifurcation can occur very close to the aorta.
     

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The SA Node is supplied by Left Coronary Artery: The sinoatrial (SA) node is usually supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) in about 60% of individuals (right-dominant circulation). In the remainder, it is supplied by the left coronary artery, specifically the circumflex artery.

 

Option B. Coronary predominance is based on the origin of Anterior Interventricular Branch: Coronary predominance refers to which coronary artery supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA). It is not based on the origin of the anterior interventricular branch (LAD artery). A right-dominant system has the PDA arising from the RCA, while a left-dominant system has it arising from the LCx.

 

Option C. The Interventricular Septum is supplied only by Right Coronary Artery: The interventricular septum is supplied by both the right and left coronary arteries. The LAD artery supplies the anterior two-thirds, including the anterior septum, while the posterior one-third can be supplied by either the RCA or LCx, depending on coronary dominance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The left coronary artery has a very short trunk before it bifurcates into the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.
  • The sinoatrial node is usually supplied by the right coronary artery in a right-dominant circulation, and the interventricular septum receives blood supply from both the left and right coronary arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is not primarily associated with a dysfunction in phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

 

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is primarily characterized by a triad of symptoms: eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and immunodeficiency.
  • It involves a defect in the WAS gene that leads to abnormality in the cytoskeleton of immune cells, affecting their ability to form the immune synapse, but it is not primarily classified as a disorder of phagocytosis.
  • This condition affects multiple aspects of the immune system, including T and B cell interactions and cell signaling, rather than directly impairing the phagocytic process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Job's syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Associated with abnormalities in phagocytosis due to STAT3 mutations affecting neutrophil chemotaxis.

 

Option B. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: A defect in vesicle trafficking that results in impaired phagocytosis among other cellular abnormalities.

 

Option C. Myeloperoxidase deficiency: While primarily affecting the killing phase post-phagocytosis, it is often studied in the context of phagocytic cell dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disorders of phagocytosis
  1. Chronic granulomatous disease
  2. Myeloperoxidase deficiency
  3. Chediak-Higashi syndrome
  4. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  5. Lazy leukocyte syndrome
  6. Job’s syndrome or Hyper-IgE syndrome
  7. Tuftsin deficiency
  8. Shwachman’s disease

choices.text: The sac contains omentum only.
The hernia lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle.
There is a patent processus vaginalis.
This type of hernia requires surgery promptly.

questions.text: For a child presenting with a groin swelling that exhibits a gurgling sound upon reduction, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The sac contains omentum only.

 

Incorrect because in the case of an indirect inguinal hernia, the sac may contain bowel, omentum, or both. A gurgling sound typically suggests the presence of bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The hernia lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle:  Correct as the indirect inguinal hernia indeed lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle, following the pathway of the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. There is a patent processus vaginalis: Correct because a patent processus vaginalis is the embryologic defect that allows for an indirect inguinal hernia to protrude.

 

Option D. This type of hernia requires surgery promptly: Correct since indirect inguinal hernias require early surgery to prevent risk of complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The statement "The sac contains omentum only" is incorrect when describing an indirect inguinal hernia in children, as these hernias may contain bowel, which is consistent with the gurgling sound heard upon reduction.
  • Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the inguinal canal, are related to a patent processus vaginalis, and are the most common type of hernia in children.

choices.text: Conducting randomized controlled trials (RCT)
Managing triage in emergency settings
Facilitating communication with a patient's family or attendants
Completing a death certificate

questions.text: The SPIKES protocol is a six-step process designed for what purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facilitating communication with a patient's family or attendants

 

  • Correct because SPIKES is a structured approach that healthcare professionals use to communicate difficult information to patients and their families in a clear, compassionate, and understanding manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conducting randomized controlled trials (RCT): Incorrect because the SPIKES protocol is not specifically designed for conducting randomized controlled trials, which are systematic studies to test new medications or treatments.

 

Option B. Managing triage in emergency settings: Incorrect as SPIKES is not a triage system used in emergency settings to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option D. Completing a death certificate: Incorrect because SPIKES is not a protocol for completing a death certificate; rather, it is for delivering serious or bad news to patients or attendants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is used to guide healthcare providers in delivering difficult or serious news to patients and their attendants, ensuring that the information is conveyed empathetically and effectively.

questions.text: A 34 years old male came with pain and watering in the right eye for 36 hours. On examination, a 3x2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger like projections and minimal hypopyon in cornea. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillosis

 

  • Aspergillosis is known for causing fungal keratitis with features such as elevated ulcer margins and feathery hyphae, making it the most likely cause in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas typically causes a more aggressive and rapidly progressing ulcer, often associated with a 'melting' appearance and severe pain, not primarily characterized by feathery hyphae.

 

Option C. Acanthamoeba: Acanthamoeba keratitis is commonly associated with contact lens wear and presents with severe pain, ring infiltrates, and stromal involvement but not typically with feathery hyphae.

 

Option D. HSV-1: HSV-1 keratitis may present with dendritic ulcers, typically seen with branching lesions and terminal bulbs, not feathery hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The feathery hyphae and finger-like projections of a corneal ulcer with minimal hypopyon are indicative of Aspergillosis, a fungal cause of keratitis, particularly in the setting of vegetative injury

choices.text: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm.
The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.
The fistula is related to pelvic radiation.
The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks.

questions.text: Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula via continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely to happen in which of the following settings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.

 

  • Spontaneous healing of genitourinary fistulas is more probable in cases where the fistula is small. Small fistulas, particularly those that are 2 to 3 mm in size, have a better chance of closing on their own with conservative management, which includes continuous bladder drainage with an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • The continuous drainage decreases urinary leakage through the fistula, reducing inflammation and allowing the surrounding tissues to heal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Larger fistulas have a significantly lower chance of spontaneous healing because the defect in the tissue is substantial, making it difficult for the surrounding tissues to close the gap without surgical intervention.

 

Option C. The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Fistulas that develop in tissues that have been damaged by radiation (radiation-induced fistulas) are less likely to heal spontaneously. Radiation causes significant fibrosis and decreased blood supply, impairing the tissue's ability to repair itself.

 

Option D. The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: While prolonged catheterization can provide continuous bladder drainage, which is beneficial, the duration alone does not guarantee fistula healing. The nature of the fistula (size, location, cause) plays a more critical role in the likelihood of spontaneous healing. Additionally, prolonged catheterization can have its own complications, such as infections or bladder irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Small genitourinary fistulas, particularly those measuring 2 to 3 mm, have a higher likelihood of spontaneous healing with conservative management, including continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • The success of this approach diminishes with larger fistulas, those caused by radiation damage, and is not solely dependent on the duration of catheterization.

choices.text: The patient with a severe head injury
The patient with airway compromise
The patient with Grade 4 shock
The patient with flail chest

questions.text: In the aftermath of a bus accident, several casualties present at the emergency department. As the attending physician following ATLS guidelines, which patient should be prioritized for immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patient with airway compromise

 

  • Airway compromise is the most immediate life-threatening condition and takes priority, as it can lead to hypoxia and death rapidly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient with a severe head injury: Severe head injuries are critical, but airway compromise poses an immediate threat to life if not addressed.

 

Option C. The patient with Grade 4 shock: While shock is a serious condition, securing the airway is the first step in the 'ABCs' of trauma management.

 

Option D. The patient with flail chest: Flail chest is a significant injury that affects breathing, but the priority is to secure the airway first to ensure oxygenation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The primary survey in trauma follows the 'ABCs' — Airway, Breathing, Circulation.
  • Airway compromise is the most acute life-threatening condition and must be addressed immediately to ensure the patient's survival.

questions.text: In a recent analysis aimed at improving immune-based therapies, a team of immunologists is categorizing cells based on their capacity to present antigens to T cells. This classification is crucial for understanding interactions that may influence therapeutic outcomes. Given this focus, which of the following cell types is not typically involved in the function of presenting antigens?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymocytes

 

  • Thymocytes are primarily immature T cells found within the thymus, where they undergo development and selection processes.
  • Unlike professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs), thymocytes do not present antigens to other immune cells to initiate or modulate immune responses; their primary role is in the maturation of T cells themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. M cells: These cells are part of the gut epithelium and play a role in transporting antigens to immune cells underneath, facilitating antigen presentation.

 

Option C. Langerhan cells: As a type of dendritic cell located in the skin, Langerhan cells are adept at capturing and presenting antigens, which is key in triggering immune responses.

 

Option D. Macrophages: Known for their ability to phagocytose pathogens and present their antigens, macrophages are central to both initiating and modulating immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymocytes are the T cells present in thymus; and T cells NEVER act as APC; infact APCs present the antigen to T cells.

questions.text: A 32-year Rh negative woman had a normal delivery after that the following test was done. What is this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kleihauer Betke Test

 

  • The Kleihauer Betke (KB) test is a special blood test used to detect fetal red blood cells present in the maternal circulation.
  • This test is particularly relevant for Rh-negative women who have given birth to a Rh-positive baby.
  • The presence of fetal red blood cells in the maternal bloodstream can lead to the development of antibodies against Rh-positive blood, which can cause complications in subsequent pregnancies with Rh-positive babies.
  • The KB test helps in quantifying the extent of fetal-maternal hemorrhage and determining the appropriate dose of Rh immunoglobulin needed to prevent Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Rosette Test: The Rosette test is another method used to screen for fetal-maternal hemorrhage in Rh-negative mothers. It's a qualitative test that can indicate whether FMH has occurred but doesn't quantify the amount of fetal blood in the maternal circulation as the Kleihauer Betke test does.

 

Option C. Peripheral Smear: A peripheral smear involves examining a sample of blood on a slide under a microscope. While it can be used to evaluate a variety of blood disorders, it's not specifically used to assess fetal-maternal hemorrhage in the context of Rh incompatibility.

 

Option D. Flow Cytometry: Flow cytometry is a technology used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of particles in a fluid as it passes through at least one laser. It can be used in a wide range of biological research and clinical practices, including immunophenotyping and assessing cell populations, but it's not the standard test for detecting fetal red blood cells in maternal blood post-delivery in the context described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Kleihauer Betke test is performed on Rh-negative women after delivery to detect and quantify fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation.
  • This helps in determining the need for and appropriate dosage of Rh immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization, which could have implications for future pregnancies.

questions.text: What is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating a child with suspected strabismus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cover Uncover Test

 

  • The Cover Uncover Test is an essential and initial evaluation in a child suspected of strabismus to differentiate between a manifest strabismus (tropia) and a latent strabismus (phoria).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced duction test: The forced duction test is used to check for restrictions in eye movements, not typically the first step in strabismus evaluation.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination: A fundus examination is important in the overall assessment of eye health but not specific for the initial evaluation of strabismus.

 

Option D. Slit lamp examination: Slit lamp examination is used to assess the anterior segment of the eye, not for the initial evaluation of strabismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cover Uncover Test is the primary investigation for a child with suspected strabismus to identify if a manifest or latent strabismus is present and determine the angle of deviation.

questions.text: In a research study focusing on the structural analysis of antibodies, a team is using papain to understand the functional components of immunoglobulins. Papain, a proteolytic enzyme, is utilized to dissect antibodies into their respective parts. Based on this application, what are the expected products when papain digests an immunoglobulin molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 Fc and 2 Fab

 

  • When papain acts on an immunoglobulin, it cleaves the molecule above the hinge region. This enzymatic action results in one Fc (fragment crystallizable) region and two Fab (fragment antigen-binding) regions.
  • This cleavage is significant because it allows the separate examination of the Fc region, which is involved in effector functions like binding to cell receptors and the complement system, and the Fab regions, which are crucial for antigen binding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 Fc and 1 Fab: Incorrect, as papain digestion produces two Fab fragments from one immunoglobulin molecule.

 

Option C. 2 Fc and 1 Fab: Incorrect, as only one Fc fragment is generated per antibody molecule.

 

Option D. 2 Fc and 2 Fab: Incorrect, because the structure of antibodies only allows for the production of one Fc and two Fab fragments upon digestion with papain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papain cleaves Ig below hinge region: produces 2 Fab + 1 Fc fragments
  • Pepsin cleaves Ig above hinge region: produces one F(ab’2) fragment + many smaller fragments

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with growth retardation and delayed developmental milestones. His hair is sparse, kinky, and breaks easily. He has a history of seizures and has been notably hypotonic since birth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Menkes disease

 

  • Menkes disease is characterized by a defect in copper transport, leading to growth retardation, hypotonia, and characteristic hair abnormalities.

 

Option B. Trisomy 21: Trisomy 21, or Down syndrome, typically presents with intellectual disability, specific facial features, and may have other systemic involvements but does not include the hair changes seen in Menkes disease.

 

Option C. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome presents with self-mutilating behaviors, intellectual disability, and signs of gout, but not typically with hair abnormalities.

 

Option D. Wilson disease: Wilson disease can cause liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms due to copper accumulation but does not present with kinky hair or early-onset growth retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features of Menkes disease are given in the question stem, which is a  X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired copper transport and utilization.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who received a kidney transplant 2 years ago and has been on chronic immunosuppressive therapy, presents with multiple hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Biopsy of one lesion confirms malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma of skin

 

  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is the most common malignancy seen in post-transplant patients due to chronic immunosuppression, particularly in sun-exposed areas, matching the presentation described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD):  PTLD refers to a range of lymphoid proliferations that can occur following transplantation due to immunosuppression. However, it does not present with hyperkeratotic skin lesions.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia can occur in the post-transplant setting but would not present with localized skin lesions, but with pancytopenia and splenomegaly.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: Kaposi’s sarcoma can occur in transplant patients but typically presents as violaceous plaques or nodules and is less common than squamous cell carcinoma in these patients.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common malignancy seen post-transplant in patients on immunosuppressive therapy is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, often occurring on sun-exposed areas.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2–3 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mittelschmerz

 

  • Mittelschmerz is a term used to describe ovulatory pain or mid-cycle pain, which typically occurs about two weeks before the onset of menstruation, corresponding to the time of ovulation in a typical menstrual cycle.
  • The pain can be sharp or cramping and is usually localized to one side of the lower abdomen, depending on which ovary is releasing an egg.
  • It generally lasts for a few hours to a couple of days and does not require treatment, although pain relief can be used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: This condition involves the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, which can cause pain, often associated with menstrual periods. While endometriosis can cause significant pelvic pain, the timing and nature of the pain described by the woman are more characteristic of ovulatory pain than endometriosis.

 

Option B. Dysmenorrhea: Dysmenorrhea refers to painful menstrual periods and is characterized by cramping pain in the lower abdomen, often accompanied by other symptoms like nausea, headache, and dizziness. The pain typically starts with the onset of menstrual bleeding, not 2 weeks before, which makes it less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Pelvic Tuberculosis: Pelvic tuberculosis is a chronic infection that can affect the reproductive organs but is relatively rare. It would typically cause more constant and severe symptoms, not cyclic pain associated with ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mittelschmerz is a benign condition characterized by unilateral, mid-cycle abdominal pain corresponding with ovulation, approximately 2 weeks prior to menstruation.

choices.text: Refer to higher center with mother giving frequent sips of ORS
Immediately admit the child, give I/V fluids and then refer to higher center
Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way
Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days

questions.text: A 2-month-old child with fever, irritability, dry oral mucosa, sunken eyes, and skin pustules is evaluated at a subcenter. The child weighs 2 kg and exhibits signs of dehydration and potential serious infection. Which initial action is most appropriate for the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way

 

  • Administering a first dose of antibiotics addresses the potential serious bacterial infection, and referring with ORS ensures ongoing hydration during transport to a higher care facility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refer to higher center with mother giving frequent sips of ORS: Simply referring to a higher center with ORS may not be adequate due to the signs of serious infection and need for immediate antibiotic treatment.

 

Option B. Immediately admit the child, give I/V fluids and then refer to higher center: Immediate admission is appropriate, but without initial antibiotic treatment, it may delay necessary management for a serious bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days: Sending the child home would be inappropriate given the signs of serious illness and risk of deterioration without prompt medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In young infants showing signs of possible serious bacterial infection and dehydration, the initial management should include administration of the first dose of antibiotics and urgent referral to a higher center with supportive hydration measures during transport.

questions.text: A patient undergoes photodynamic therapy (PDT) for a neovascular retinal lesion. Following the procedure, the ophthalmologist observes changes in the color of the lesion. What is the immediate post-procedural colour change of the lesion typically seen after photodynamic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White

 

  • Immediately following PDT, a lesion typically becomes white due to the whitening of the deep retinal layers and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes induced by the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Same: The lesion would not retain the same color immediately after PDT due to photodynamic activation and subsequent tissue changes.

 

Option B. Grey: Grey coloration may represent a later stage in the healing process or a different ocular pathology but is not the immediate change post-PDT.

 

Option C. Yellow: Yellow coloration might be seen in different ocular conditions like drusen or lipid exudates but is not the characteristic immediate color change following PDT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The immediate post-procedural color change of a lesion after photodynamic therapy is that it typically appears white, reflecting the photodynamic effects on neovascular and surrounding tissue within the retina.

choices.text: Surgery to remove the obstruction
Administration of medications to relieve pain
Feeding the patient to promote weight gain
Endoscopic intervention to widen the narrowed angle

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She reports weight loss following a keto-diet in the past few months. On investigation, the small bowel appears normal, but a CECT of the abdomen reveals compression of the D3 segment of the duodenum due to narrowing of the angle of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Which of the following is the best option for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding the patient to promote weight gain

 

  • In the context of SMA Syndrome, or Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome, it is essential to understand the treatment options based on the pathophysiology of the condition.
  • The primary conservative treatment for SMA Syndrome is to increase the mesenteric fat pad, which separates the SMA from the aorta, thereby relieving the compression on the duodenum. This is typically achieved by nutritional support to promote weight gain.

 

Option A: Surgery to remove the obstruction: Surgical intervention may be considered if conservative measures fail. It is not the first line of treatment because the syndrome is often caused by a lack of mesenteric fat padding, not an actual physical obstruction that needs to be removed.

 

Option B: Administration of medications to relieve pain: While pain management is an important aspect of patient care, medications alone will not address the underlying issue of the narrowed angle between the SMA and the aorta, which is causing the duodenal compression.

 

Option D: Endoscopic intervention to widen the narrowed angle: Endoscopic intervention is not the standard treatment for SMA Syndrome because the problem is not within the duodenal lumen but rather external compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The initial treatment for SMA Syndrome is conservative, focusing on nutritional support to promote weight gain and increase the mesenteric fat pad, thereby relieving the compression of the duodenum.

choices.text: Continue with the same antibiotic but in a higher dose
Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone

questions.text: During rounds in the hospital's infectious disease unit, a medical team reviews a case of a patient treated with ceftriaxone and amikacin. Recent culture results indicate that an ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase) producing Klebsiella species has been identified. Given the resistance profile of ESBL-producing organisms, which of the following adjustments to the patient's antibiotic regimen would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone

 

  • Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone is the best choice.
  • ESBL-producing bacteria are resistant to most beta-lactam antibiotics, including third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.
  • Imipenem, a carbapenem, is generally effective against ESBL-producing organisms because it is stable against the beta-lactamase enzymes they produce.
  • Therefore, replacing ceftriaxone with imipenem addresses the resistance issue and provides an effective treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue with the same antibiotic but in a higher dose: This approach is ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms, as resistance is not overcome by increasing the dose of an antibiotic that the organism already resists.

 

Option B. Change ceftriaxone and add ceftazidime: Ceftazidime, a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone, is also ineffective against ESBL-producing Klebsiella due to similar resistance mechanisms.

 

Option D. Remove Amikacin: This option does not address the primary issue of ceftriaxone resistance. While adjusting amikacin may be considered depending on the sensitivity profile, the key change needed involves addressing the beta-lactam resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ESBL (Extended spectrum beta lactamases) are resistant to all Penicillin and 1st/2nd/3rd cephalosporin and monobactam; which can be overcome by addition of β lactamase inhibitor

like clavulanic acid other alternate which can be given are:

 

  • Carbapenems like Imipenem and meropenem
  • Cephamycins (like cefoxitin and cefotetan )
  • Different class of antibiotics like aminoglycoside

choices.text: Observe with antibiotic cover
Re-explore the wound with T-tube insertion
Pigtail insertion and drainage
ERCP and proceed

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who recently had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy presents on postoperative day 3 with fever. An ultrasonographic evaluation reveals a 5x5 cm fluid collection in the right subdiaphragmatic space. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pigtail insertion and drainage

 

  • Given scenario is suggestive of acute bile duct injury, which requires drainage of leaked bile (bilioma) as the first step.
  • Perform percutaneous drainage with a pigtail catheter, which is a minimally invasive procedure to drain collections and is often the first-line treatment for abscesses or significant symptomatic fluid collections.

 

Option A. Observe with antibiotic cover: Administer antibiotics and observe, considering that postoperative fluid collections can be managed conservatively if they are not causing significant symptoms or showing signs of infection.

 

Option B. Re-explore the wound with T-tube insertion: Re-explore the surgical wound with the possibility of T-tube insertion, which may be considered for bile leaks or biliary injury, though this is typically confirmed before such an invasive procedure.

 

Option D. ERCP and proceed: Conduct an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), which is instrumental for diagnosing and managing biliary tract complications but may not be the initial approach for simple fluid collections without evidence of biliary leak or obstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In postoperative patients presenting with fever and localized fluid collections, percutaneous drainage under imaging guidance is a less invasive and effective intervention to resolve the collection and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

  • Methotrexate, a folic acid antagonist, is a non-surgical treatment option for ectopic pregnancy in hemodynamically stable patients with no significant pain, an unruptured ectopic mass typically smaller than 3-4 cm, and low and stable hCG levels (less than 5000 IU/L).
  • Single-dose methotrexate injection can be an effective treatment, leading to the resolution of the ectopic pregnancy without the need for surgery.
  • The patient's hCG levels are monitored after treatment to ensure they decline appropriately, indicating resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Methotrexate for the treatment of ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via intramuscular injection, not orally, to ensure appropriate absorption and therapeutic levels.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This regimen is considered in cases where the ectopic pregnancy doesn't respond to a single dose of methotrexate, or in certain cases of higher initial hCG levels or larger ectopic mass. Leucovorin is a folinic acid used to rescue normal cells from the effects of methotrexate in higher or multi-dose regimens.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: This surgical option involves the removal of the affected fallopian tube and is considered in cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the ectopic pregnancy has ruptured, or there is a contraindication to or failure of medical management. Given the patient's stability and the characteristics of the adnexal mass, conservative medical management with methotrexate is preferred initially.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected ectopic pregnancy, a single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate initial management strategy, especially when the ectopic mass is small (less than 3-4 cm) and hCG levels are low (less than 5000 IU/L).
  • This approach can effectively resolve the ectopic pregnancy without the need for surgical intervention, preserving the patient's reproductive potential.

choices.text: Both Pfu Polymerase and Taq Polymerase

questions.text: Which of the following polymerases are known to have proofreading abilities that ensure high fidelity during PCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pfu Polymerase

 

  • Pfu Polymerase is the correct choice because it possesses 3' to 5' exonuclease activity, which allows it to remove incorrectly paired bases during DNA synthesis, enhancing the accuracy of the PCR product.
  • This proofreading ability is crucial for applications requiring high-fidelity DNA amplification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taq Polymerase: This is a common choice for PCR due to its efficiency and robustness, but it lacks proofreading ability because it does not have the 3' to 5' exonuclease activity necessary for correcting errors in DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. Both Pfu Polymerase and Taq Polymerase: This choice is incorrect because, although both are used in PCR, only Pfu has proofreading capabilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pfu DNA polymerase, derived from Pyrococcus furiosus, has superior thermostability and proofreading properties compared to other thermostable polymerase such as Taq polymerase.

choices.text: Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery
Right renal vein is longer than left renal vein
Left renal artery is longer than right renal artery
The anterior most structure at renal hilum is the renal artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the kidney?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

 

  • Due to the position of the aorta to the left of the midline and the inferior vena cava to the right, the right renal artery must travel a longer distance to reach the right kidney compared to the left renal artery.
  • This is why the right renal artery is typically longer than the left.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right renal vein is longer than left renal vein: In fact, the left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein because the left renal vein has to cross the midline in front of the aorta to reach the inferior vena cava, while the right renal vein has a shorter and more direct path to the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Left renal artery is longer than right renal artery: The left renal artery is no longer than the right; it is typically shorter because the aorta lies closer to the left kidney.

 

Option D. The anterior most structure at renal hilum is the renal artery: In the typical anatomical arrangement, the most anterior structure at the renal hilum is the renal vein. The sequence from anterior to posterior is usually the renal vein, followed by the renal artery, and then the renal pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery due to the relative positions of the aorta and the inferior vena cava, which necessitates a longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney.

questions.text:
Chocolate agar, a variant of blood agar where blood cells have been lysed by heating, is used primarily to isolate fastidious organisms. Which of the following organisms can grow on chocolate agar? 

 

  1. Neisseria meningitidis
  2. Haemophilus influenzae
  3. Vibrio cholerae
  4. Listeria monocytogenes
  5. Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • All of the listed organisms can grow on chocolate agar.
  • Chocolate agar is enriched with nutrients and the lysed blood cells provide factors like hemin and NAD (factor V) which are essential for the growth of certain fastidious organisms.
  • Here's how each organism utilizes the medium:
    • Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae are particularly reliant on the factors provided by chocolate agar for their growth, as they are fastidious.
    • Vibrio cholerae, Listeria monocytogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus are not as fastidious but can still grow on chocolate agar due to its rich nutrient content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chocolate agar (an Enriched media): It is the heated blood agar, blood is added to the molten nutrient agar at 70°C. It is more nutritious than blood agar

questions.text: A 25-year primi with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS (Lower segment caesarean surgery). Following delivery of the baby, this was the appearance of the uterus. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio Placenta

 

  • Preeclampsia is a condition characterized by high blood pressure and often proteinuria in pregnancy, which can increase the risk of placental complications.
  • Abruptio placenta, or premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, is a serious complication that can occur in the setting of preeclampsia and is known to cause fetal distress.
  • The appearance of the uterus after delivery could show signs of abruption, such as retroplacental clots or an irregular placental surface.
  • Fetal distress in this context could be due to the decreased oxygen and nutrient delivery to the fetus because of the compromised placental function.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetus and the mother's pelvis, making it difficult for the baby to pass through the birth canal during vaginal delivery. While CPD can result in prolonged labor and potential fetal distress, it does not directly relate to changes in the appearance of the uterus observed during cesarean delivery and is less likely in the context of preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: Meconium staining of the amniotic fluid can be a sign of fetal distress, but it is not a direct cause. It's more of an indicator that the fetus experienced stress at some point during labor. The appearance of the uterus itself would not necessarily be affected by the presence of meconium in the amniotic fluid.

 

Option D. Utero-placental insufficiency: Utero-placental insufficiency refers to inadequate blood flow to the placenta, resulting in insufficient oxygen and nutrients reaching the fetus. While preeclampsia can contribute to utero-placental insufficiency and subsequently fetal distress, abruptio placenta is a more acute and specific complication that would explain both the fetal distress and potential abnormal findings in the uterus after delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of preeclampsia and fetal distress necessitating an emergency cesarean section, abruptio placenta is a plausible cause of fetal distress, particularly if there are abnormal findings in the uterus after delivery.
  • This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to decreased placental function and fetal distress.

questions.text: Identifying organisms that can resist moist environments is crucial for maintaining sterile conditions. Which bacterium is known for its ability to often contaminate disinfectant solutions?
questions.solution:
Ans: D) Pseudomonas

 

  • Pseudomonas, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa, is the correct answer because this bacterium is notorious for its ability to survive in moist environments and resist many common disinfectants and antiseptics.
  • It can grow in disinfectant solutions, leading to contamination that can be challenging to eradicate in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus is a common pathogen in healthcare settings, it is not particularly known for contaminating disinfectant solutions.

 

Option B. Streptococcus: This genus of bacteria, although a frequent pathogen in humans, does not typically survive well in the harsh conditions of disinfectants.

 

Option C. E. coli: Escherichia coli is another common bacterium but does not typically contaminate disinfectant solutions; it is more associated with gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomonas is resistant to no. of disinfectant solutions such as savlon or Dettol.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche – absent
  • FSH, LH – high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

  • The key features in this case are the absence of breast development (thelarche), elevated gonadotropins (FSH, LH), and a normal 46 XX karyotype.
  • These findings suggest a condition where the ovaries (gonads) are not functioning properly despite the presence of two X chromosomes, leading to primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual characteristics due to insufficient estrogen production.
  • Gonadal dysgenesis encompasses a spectrum of disorders where the gonads (in this case, the ovaries) are partially or completely dysfunctional.
  • Pure gonadal dysgenesis can occur with a normal 46 XX karyotype, where the individual has a female genotype and phenotype but with streak ovaries that are non-functional, leading to high levels of FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from estrogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome: Also known as Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), this condition is characterized by a 46 XY karyotype in someone with a phenotypically female appearance due to the body's inability to respond to androgens. This would not fit with the 46 XX karyotype provided.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism associated with a lack of sense of smell, due to a deficiency in GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone). Patients typically have low levels of gonadotropins (FSH, LH), which is not consistent with the high levels described in this case.

 

Option D. Turner syndrome: This condition involves a 45 X karyotype (or variations thereof) and is associated with short stature, webbed neck, and other phenotypic features, none of which are described in this case. Moreover, the karyotype provided is 46 XX, which rules out Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of primary amenorrhea, lack of breast development, high FSH and LH levels, and a normal 46 XX karyotype suggest gonadal dysgenesis, a condition where the gonads are non-functional despite the individual having a typical female chromosomal makeup.
  • This leads to primary amenorrhea and lack of development of secondary sexual characteristics due to insufficient sex steroid production.

choices.text: Type of glass lens used

questions.text: During a laboratory training session, a group of postgraduate students is instructed on the operation and maintenance of an electron microscope. The instructor emphasizes the critical factors that can influence the performance and resolution of the microscope. Which of the following is a key factor affecting the functioning of an electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thickness of the sample

 

  • The correct answer is (d) Thickness of the sample. In electron microscopy, the sample thickness plays a critical role in determining image quality.
  • Electron microscopes use a beam of electrons rather than light to create an image.
  • If a sample is too thick, it can scatter the electrons too much, which reduces the clarity and detail of the image.
  • Optimizing sample thickness is crucial for obtaining high-resolution images and accurate data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eyepiece: Electron microscopes do not typically use an eyepiece like optical microscopes. Instead, they produce an image on a phosphorescent screen or capture it digitally.

 

Option B. Wavelength of the light: This is irrelevant for electron microscopes, which do not use light waves; they operate using electron beams, where the wavelength of the electrons (much shorter than that of light) allows for higher resolution.

 

Option C. Type of glass lens used: Electron microscopes do not use glass lenses. Instead, they utilize electromagnetic lenses to focus the electron beam.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In order to get visualized by EM, the specimen should be very thin (20 to 100 nm thickness).

choices.text: It is used to inhibit inappropriate lactation with secondary amenorrhoea
It is specific in suppressing only the prolactin secretion
If pregnancy occurs, there is increased incidence of multiple pregnancy
Its teratogenic effect on the fetus is inconclusive

questions.text: The following are related to bromocriptine therapy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If pregnancy occurs, there is increased incidence of multiple pregnancy

 

  • Bromocriptine does not increase the incidence of multiple pregnancies. It is used to treat conditions like hyperprolactinemia, which can cause infertility.
  • By lowering prolactin levels, bromocriptine can restore ovulation and fertility, but it does not inherently increase the risk of multiple pregnancies like some other fertility treatments (e.g., gonadotropins).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It is used to inhibit inappropriate lactation with secondary amenorrhea: This is true. Bromocriptine can be used to treat conditions associated with hyperprolactinemia, including inappropriate lactation and secondary amenorrhea.
