Option B. It is specific in suppressing only the prolactin secretion: While bromocriptine is primarily used to suppress prolactin secretion, its specificity is not absolute. Dopamine agonists can have varied effects on neurotransmission and other hormone levels, but bromocriptine is most commonly associated with reducing prolactin levels.

 

Option D. Its teratogenic effect on the fetus is inconclusive: There has been concern about the potential teratogenic effects of bromocriptine, especially when used in early pregnancy. However, extensive data has not conclusively demonstrated a significant risk of birth defects associated with its use. It's generally advised to discontinue bromocriptine once pregnancy is confirmed, primarily due to a lack of necessity as prolactin levels naturally rise during pregnancy without the adverse effects seen in hyperprolactinemia.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Bromocriptine therapy is not associated with an increased incidence of multiple pregnancies.
  • Its primary use in reproductive medicine is to treat conditions related to hyperprolactinemia, such as inappropriate lactation and amenorrhea, by suppressing prolactin secretion.

questions.text: Identify the type of covering used for burns wound:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch graft

 

  • The meshed partial thickness skin graft shown here is Thiersch graft
  • A Thiersch graft, also known as a split-thickness skin graft (STSG), is a skin graft that includes the epidermis and a portion of the dermis.
  • This graft, as shown in the image, is a partial thickness skin graft that includes the epidermis and a part of the dermis. It's used to cover large wound areas, such as burn wounds, and can be meshed to cover a larger area, which seems to be the case in the provided image.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Free Flap: A free flap is a type of graft that involves the transfer of tissue, including skin, muscle, fat, or a combination thereof, along with its own blood supply. It is not the graft shown in the image.

 

Option B. Full Thickness Graft: A full-thickness skin graft consists of the epidermis and the entire dermis. It is taken from donor sites that can be closed directly and is not what's depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Free Radial Artery Forearm Flap: This is a type of free flap taken from the forearm and includes skin, subcutaneous tissue, and the radial artery. It is not relevant to the meshed graft shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Thiersch graft, a split-thickness skin graft, involves the transplantation of epidermis and part of the dermis from a donor site to a wound, commonly used for large burn injuries due to its ability to cover extensive areas and facilitate wound healing.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida is admitted at 39 weeks gestation with painless antepartum hemorrhage. On examination uterus is soft non-tender and head engaged. The management for her would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trans vaginal ultrasound

 

  • Painless antepartum hemorrhage is highly suggestive of placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or wholly covers the cervix.
  • The key in managing such a situation, is to confirm the diagnosis.
  • This is best done by a TVS. If confirmed, the patient needs to be delivered by cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood transfusion and sedatives: While stabilization of the patient's condition, including blood transfusion if needed, is crucial in the management of antepartum hemorrhage, sedatives are not typically a part of the initial management strategy. The primary focus should be on diagnosing the cause of the hemorrhage and planning the appropriate intervention.

 

Option B. A speculum examination: While a speculum examination can be useful in evaluating the source of bleeding, it is generally avoided in cases of suspected placenta previa due to the risk of provoking further bleeding. The initial assessment should be non-invasive, such as ultrasound, to avoid disrupting the placenta.

 

Option D. Tocolysis and sedatives: Tocolysis, the use of medications to suppress uterine contractions, is not indicated in this scenario. The primary concern in painless antepartum hemorrhage is to identify the source of bleeding and manage it appropriately, not to delay labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of a primigravida at term with painless antepartum hemorrhage, a careful pelvic examination in the operating theatre is recommended to assess the situation while being prepared for potential immediate surgical intervention, considering the high suspicion for placenta previa or another placental issue.
  • This approach allows for rapid response to the findings and minimizes the risk to both mother and baby.

questions.text: Which of the following is an antagonist of a peptide and is used to reduce chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aprepitant

 

  • Aprepitant is an antagonist of the neurokinin-1 (NK1) receptor, which binds the peptide substance P, a key neurotransmitter involved in the vomiting reflex.
  • By blocking this receptor, aprepitant effectively reduces the likelihood of nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, making it a crucial component of antiemetic regimens, particularly in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial natriuretic peptide: This peptide is involved in the regulation of fluid and electrolyte homeostasis and blood pressure but is not used to manage chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

 

Option C. Bradykinin: While bradykinin is a peptide that plays a role in inflammatory responses and can affect vascular permeability and pain sensation, it is not used as an antagonist in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Enalapril: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of hypertension and certain types of heart failure. It works by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II and is unrelated to the treatment of nausea and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aprepitant is used as an NK1 receptor antagonist to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by blocking the action of substance P at neurokinin-1 receptors in the brain's vomiting center.
  • This makes it an effective part of the regimen for managing nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, particularly in patients receiving highly emetogenic treatments.

questions.text:
During a training session for emergency responders, a discussion focuses on the categorization of bioterrorism agents according to their threat level and potential for public health impact. Which organisms are included in Category ‘A’ for bioterrorism threats, indicating the highest priority organisms that pose a risk to national security?

 

  1. Vibrio cholera
  2. Clostridium botulinum
  3. Yersinia pestis
  4. Bacillus anthracis
  5. Burkholderia mallei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

  • Category A bioterrorism agents can be easily disseminated, have high mortality rates and lead to public panic & disruption
  • Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin, one of the most potent known toxins, which can result in severe and often fatal paralysis.
  • Yersinia pestis is the causative agent of plague, an infectious disease that has caused widespread pandemics with high mortality rates throughout history.
  • Bacillus anthracis is known for causing anthrax, which can be lethal when spores are inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera, the agent causing cholera, can lead to significant outbreaks and public health challenges, it is not classified under Category ‘A’ because it has lower mortality when treated and is less likely to cause social disruption comparable to Category ‘A’ agents.

 

Option 5. Burkholderia mallei: Although Burkholderia mallei, which causes glanders, is a serious pathogen, it is not typically classified under Category ‘A’. It does pose a risk but does not match the criteria of ease of dissemination and high mortality as closely as the Category ‘A’ agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Category A Bioterrorism agents (WHO) include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Smallpox, Plague, Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Filoviruses – Ebola & Marburg; Arenaviruses – Lassa, Machupo)

questions.text: An alcoholic developed intractable vomiting for 2 days with loose motions. Since he had decreased food intake and altered sensorium, he was brought to the hospital, where the fluid loss and dyselectrolytemia was aggressively corrected with fluid infusion. Post treatment, the patient started having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), previously known as central pontine myelinolysis, can occur when there is a rapid correction of hyponatremia.
  • This condition is especially a risk in malnourished patients such as those with chronic alcoholism.
  • The rapid shift in serum osmolality can lead to demyelination, predominantly in the central pons, but it can also affect extrapontine areas.
  • The clinical manifestation of quadriplegia and mutism after an aggressive correction of electrolyte imbalance in an alcoholic patient is highly suggestive of ODS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndrome of inappropriate ADH production (SIADH): SIADH would lead to hyponatremia, but on its own, it does not explain the neurological symptoms seen post rapid correction.

 

Option C. Brain stem infarct: While a brain stem infarct could cause similar neurological deficits, the context of rapid electrolyte correction leading to these symptoms points away from an infarct.

 

Option D. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM): ADEM typically occurs after an infection or vaccination and involves widespread demyelination in the brain and spinal cord. It's usually not associated with the correction of electrolytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The rapid correction of hyponatremia, particularly in individuals who are malnourished or chronically ill (such as those with chronic alcoholism), can lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome.
  • This is characterized by neurological symptoms that can develop days after the overly rapid correction of sodium levels.
  • Care must be taken to correct sodium slowly in at-risk patients to prevent this serious complication.
